source.author: Gebauer, R.
source.title: Parietaria
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Gebauer, R. (1996). Parietaria. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Annual or short-lived perennial herb; leaves with 3 separate nerves; inflorescence with a central bisexual flower (lateral flowers female or bisexual); each flower subtended by 1–3 bracts; stigma sessile

Perennial herb with woody base; leaves with midrib divided into 3; inflorescence with central female flower and lateral bisexual flowers, bracts of each inflorescence forming a common involucre; stigma on a long style
Bracts subtending lateral flowers often fused at base, lanceolate or ovate, with obscure or delicate reticulate venation
Bracts subtending lateral flowers free, heart-shaped, with conspicuous reticulate venation; rare plant of north-west

Bracts subtending lateral flowers nearly equal in length broadly triangular-ovate, concealing the flowers entirely except for perianth tips, initially delicate and green but becoming brown and often harder at maturity, delicate reticulate venation visible; achene delicate, pale brown to pale greenish-brown; Grampians, Mt Langi Ghiran and further north

Bracts subtending lateral flowers of unequal length (the central bract shorter than the two lateral ones), narrowly lanceolate to ovate, incompletely hiding the lateral flowers, remaining soft and green at maturity, reticulation lacking or very delicate; achene hard, medium to dark brown; widespread
